Award.AwardTitle: A Manufacturing Process for Producing Thick Films with Controlled Microstructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Patterned thick films are used in the manufacture of integrated circuits and sensors for applications ranging from camera sensors, to medical implants, to computer networks. Currently, most thick films are produced by a screen printing process, which involves deposition of pastes containing fine metal particles which are then heated to high temperatures to bond the particles so that the conductivity is increased to an acceptable level. The need for high processing temperature limits the choices of substrates upon which the films can be deposited, and often requires expensive and rigid glass or ceramic substrates. This award supports research towards advancing a new method for depositing thick films that can dramatically reduce processing temperatures and would allow deposition on lower-cost and flexible substrates, while also allowing novel material structures that have the potential to produce films with superior properties. Such patterned films that exhibit improved properties would have applications in many devices including high power electronics and solar cells, and other applications that could advance US competitiveness in manufacturing. The multidisciplinary approach which involves a combination of computer simulations and experiments will enable the education of graduate students, and the outreach activities will integrate this research with a proven program that enables high school teachers to effectively teach engineering to encourage and prepare their students to enter engineering and science careers.

The laser ablation of microparticle aerosol process is a relatively new process for depositing patterned, micro-scale thick films with nanostructured features. Nanoparticles are produced from commonly available and inexpensive powders via an aerosol ablation and then impacted at high velocities onto a substrate. High production rates allow direct writing of inorganic (metallic, semiconductor, or ceramic) thick films without a mask at room temperature onto polymeric, metallic, or ceramic substrates. The grain size and porosity in the films can be controlled through the ablation and deposition parameters. The current process, however, is limited to producing polycrystalline or amorphous films with a maximum as-deposited relative density of about 70 percent. A combination of predictive molecular dynamics computer simulations and experimental studies of the nanoparticle impaction and film growth processes are planned to develop an understanding of how processing parameters influence deposition efficiency, the film morphology, and film structure on a nano- to-micro scale. Computer simulations will be used to systematically study the influence of particle size, impaction energy, substrate temperature, material composition and crystallinity, defect orientation and concentration, and particle/substrate misorientation on the resulting films. In combination with the computer simulations, the experimental apparatus will be modified to allow experiments to be conducted under conditions in which the simulations can be validated. The experimental data will be used to modify the computer simulations as needed so that accurate predictions of the resulting film microstructures can be made. It is expected that by studying the factors that control deposition and film growth will lead to a much larger range of microstructures and densities than is currently possible, including single crystal patterned films with relative densities approaching 100 percent.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The laser ablation of microparticle aerosol (LAMA) process is used to deposit patterned, micro-scale thick films with nanostructured features. Nanoparticles are produced from commonly available and inexpensive powders via an aerosol ablation and then impacted at high velocities onto a substrate.  High production rates allow direct writing of inorganic (metallic, semiconductor, or ceramic) thick films (1-100 µm) without a mask at room temperature onto polymeric, metallic, or ceramic substrates. The grain size and porosity in the films can be controlled through the ablation parameters and deposition parameters. The current process, however, is limited to producing polycrystalline or amorphous films with a maximum as-deposited relative density of about 70%. Patterned films such as these that display improved properties have applications in many devices including high power electronics, laser waveguides, and hybrid solar cells. 

A combination of predictive molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and experimental studies of the nanoparticle impact and film growth processes were studied to develop an understanding of how processing parameters influence deposition efficiency, the film morphology, and film structure on a nano-to-micro scale. MD simulations were used to systematically study the influence of particle size, impact energy, defect orientation and concentration, and particle/substrate misorientation on the resulting films.  To complement the simulations, the LAMA apparatus was be modified to allow deposition energies of 0.1 – 2.4 eV/atom and a separate aerosol deposition system was implemented so that MD simulation results could be tested experimentally and the simulation process validated. The resulting films were studied by a combination of optical, scanning electron, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and by x-ray diffraction to quantify their nano-to-microstructure. Understanding the factors that control deposition and film growth has allowed patterned films with a larger range of microstructures and densities will be possible prior to the research project. 

 

Intellectual Merit of Proposed Activities
The intellectual merit of the proposed project is a systematic computational and experimental study of the mechanisms of nanoparticle deformation and film growth that will enable a manufacturing process for producing patterned thick films with a range of film morphologies, materials, and microstructures that are difficult or impossible to produce using any single existing manufacturing process.

Broader Impacts of Proposed Activities

The broader impacts of this proposal are multifold. The proposed research has resulted in a flexible and environmentally friendly manufacturing process for producing patterned thick films that should enable new technologies and improve existing ones. The fundamental knowledge gained from the proposed work also improves our understanding of other manufacturing processes that utilize particle impaction such as the aerosol deposition method and the cold spray process. Simulation tools that can be used to further develop these and similar particle deposition processes have been developed and validated. The results of the research have and will be disseminated broadly by presentation at disciplinary conferences and by publication in peer reviewed journals. The proposed has also enabled the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the outreach activities to high school students has effectively motivated and better prepared these students to enter engineering or science careers.

Modified by: Desiderio Kovar

The grain size in the resulting film of approximately 25 nm is direct evidence that particle coarsening processes occur when the particles impact onto the substrate.   • Cross-sections of an Ag line. Lines such as these which are thick relative to their deposit widths and exhibit increasing porosity with line thickness. It was shown that there is a critical normal impact velocity for attaining high density films.
    J. McCallister, J. Keto, M. Becker, and D. Kovar

  • Plot of potential energy (PE) versus time for 12 atoms that are located at different locations in a nanoparticle that is impacting a substrate at 300 m/sec. Disordering occurs at a critical PE of -2.709 Â± 0.04 ev/atom.

  • TEM following impact of a smaller 13.6 nm particle onto a larger 32 nm particle. The impact has resulted in an epitaxial deposition, e.g. the two particles have the same crystallographic orientations as shown by the continuous lattice fringes across the regions of the two particles.     T. Chitrikar, J. Keto, M. Becker, D. Kovar

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The laser ablation of microparticle aerosol (LAMA) process is used to deposit patterned, micro-scale thick films with nanostructured features. Nanoparticles are produced from commonly available and inexpensive powders via an aerosol ablation and then impacted at high velocities onto a substrate. High production rates allow direct writing of inorganic (metallic, semiconductor, or ceramic) thick films (1-100 µm) without a mask at room temperature onto polymeric, metallic, or ceramic substrates. The grain size and porosity in the films can be controlled through the ablation parameters and deposition parameters. The current process, however, is limited to producing polycrystalline or amorphous films with a maximum as-deposited relative density of about 70%. Patterned films such as these that display improved properties have applications in many devices including high power electronics, laser waveguides, and hybrid solar cells. A combination of predictive molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and experimental studies of the nanoparticle impact and film growth processes were studied to develop an understanding of how processing parameters influence deposition efficiency, the film morphology, and film structure on a nano-to-micro scale. MD simulations were used to systematically study the influence of particle size, impact energy, defect orientation and concentration, and particle/substrate misorientation on the resulting films. To complement the simulations, the LAMA apparatus was be modified to allow deposition energies of 0.1 – 2.4 eV/atom and a separate aerosol deposition system was implemented so that MD simulation results could be tested experimentally and the simulation process validated. The resulting films were studied by a combination of optical, scanning electron, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and by x-ray diffraction to quantify their nano-to-microstructure. Understanding the factors that control deposition and film growth has allowed patterned films with a larger range of microstructures and densities will be possible prior to the research project. Intellectual Merit of Proposed Activities The intellectual merit of the proposed project is a systematic computational and experimental study of the mechanisms of nanoparticle deformation and film growth that will enable a manufacturing process for producing patterned thick films with a range of film morphologies, materials, and microstructures that are difficult or impossible to produce using any single existing manufacturing process. Broader Impacts of Proposed Activities The broader impacts of this proposal are multifold. The proposed research has resulted in a flexible and environmentally friendly manufacturing process for producing patterned thick films that should enable new technologies and improve existing ones. The fundamental knowledge gained from the proposed work also improves our understanding of other manufacturing processes that utilize particle impaction such as the aerosol deposition method and the cold spray process. Simulation tools that can be used to further develop these and similar particle deposition processes have been developed and validated. The results of the research have and will be disseminated broadly by presentation at disciplinary conferences and by publication in peer reviewed journals. The proposed has also enabled the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the outreach activities to high school students has effectively motivated and better prepared these students to enter engineering or science careers.
